question: Specific term required. One of these people died while leading an ill-fated expedition whose few survivors included the enslaved man Estevanico. One of these people known as “the Madman” styled himself the “Wrath of God, Prince of Freedom.” Several of these people funded monuments in their hometowns across Extremadura. One of these people wrote a “true history” that recounts how another of them wept during a 1520 event which translates to “The  Sad Night.” A woman who translated for one of these people was known as “La Malinche.” After winning the Battle of Cajamarca , one of these people ordered Atahualpa’s  execution. For 10 points, give the Spanish or Portuguese term for soldier-explorers like Hernán Cortés, who conquered much of the Americas.

This modern-day country contains a fractally designed wall that may be the world’s largest man-made earthwork structure. In this country, an archaeologist observed a farmer using a Nok terracotta head as a scarecrow. The influence of the Ọọ̀ni of Ilé-Ifẹ̀  in this country was eclipsed by the Oyo Empire. In this country, the city-states of Zazzau and Gobir were conquered by  Usman dan Fodio during the 19th-century Fulani jihads. This country’s  western neighbor shares its name with a set of bronzes that Henry Rawson pillaged from a kingdom in this country. Obas ruled this country’s south while Hausa kings controlled its north. For 10 points, name this modern-day country home to the Igbo and Yoruba people.

Austria’s “Dapper” Joe Farren ran chorus lines in this city during an era where the rich patronized the Art Deco Paramount nightclub on Bubbling Well Road. This city was where the “January Storm” that purged the Four Olds took place and names a 1972 Communique where the Nixon administration “acknowledged” claims on Taiwan. The  Pǔdōng New Area in this city benefited from the creation of a Special Economic Zone in 1993 and lies across the river from The Bund. The opening of the Yángshān Port in 2005 helped this city become the busiest container port in the world. It’s not Shēnzhèn, but in 1990, Dèng Xiǎopíng re-opened a stock exchange in this city. For 10 points, name this financial capital of China.

A man with this surname names a town where Stonewall Jackson’s forces killed Colonel Dixon S. Miles before capturing a Union garrison in September 1862. Brothers with this surname founded a publication that originally published The “Brains” and other cartoons by Thomas Nast. George Washington’s grandnephew Lewis was taken hostage in a town named for this surname in an incident resolved by troops under  Robert E. Lee. That town named for a person with this surname housed the second-ever US Armory, a facility captured in 1859 in a failed attempt to spark a slave revolt. For 10 points, give this surname in the name of a West Virginia town targeted by abolitionist John Brown.

In this city, Demetrio Vallejo was accused of plotting with a Soviet embassy during a 1959 rail strike. In 2006, this city was occupied for 47 days by protestors demanding that the TEPJF issue a recount. A paramilitary group called The Falcons lend their name to a massacre in this city that took place during a Corpus Christi festival in 1971. President  Miguel de la Madrid was heckled after an earthquake devastated this city in 1986. Over 300 student protestors were killed in this city in 1968 in the lead-up to an Olympics where John Carlos and Tommie Smith made a Black Power salute. The Tlatelolco  Massacre took place in, for 10 points, what capital of a country ruled by the PRI while a one-time member of NAFTA?

In 2023, the International African American Museum opened in this state’s Gadsden’s Wharf. After its legislature closed his school, Daniel Payne left this state and joined the AME Church. In this state, a group of mainly Congolese slaves chanted “Liberty” while being led by Cato in the largest British colonial slave revolt. A failed slave revolt on Bastille Day in this state was planned by a man who purchased his freedom with his lottery winnings,  Denmark Vesey. The Stono Rebellion occurred in this state. In the Antebellum period, this state had the largest proportion of Black to white residents due to its rice and indigo plantations. For 10 points, name this state which had slave markets in Charleston.

A refugee from this government known as Queen Monique set off a craze for wearing pink in China. Because this government destroyed almost all cameras, the 2013 documentary The Missing Picture used stop-motion animation. The first man charged by the Extraordinary Chambers in the Courts for actions taken during this government’s reign was Comrade Duch . After declaring a  “Year Zero,” this government sent New People to “interrogation centers,” which housed supporters of the exiled king Sihanouk . This government turned a high school into a notorious death camp at S-21, which continued to torture prisoners even as the Vietnamese Army invaded. For 10 points, name this government headed by Pol Pot that ruled Cambodia.

The fifteen “Proven Companions” of this battle’s victor are the only people known to have fought for its winning side. The night before this battle, the losing side camped on Caldbec Hill near a “hoar apple tree” before moving to Senlac Hill the next day. This battle’s losing commander died alongside his brothers Gyrth and Leofwine during it. This battle’s victor landed at  Pevensey briefly before it and was crowned later the same year on Christmas Day. Bishop Odo commissioned an artwork that depicts this battle’s loser dying from an arrow in his eye. The Bayeux  Tapestry depicts Harold Godwinson’s death during, for 10 points, what 1066 CE victory for William the Conqueror?

Description acceptable. During the English Civil War, William Dowsing was nicknamed for vigorously enforcing this policy as per a law that called out rood lofts. A decree by Yazid II may have inspired a later policy of this type whose end in 843 CE is celebrated on the Feast of Orthodoxy. A “fury” of this policy took place during Germany’s Bildersturm in the 16th century. One of these policies was applied to the Temples of Bel and Baalshamin in  Palmyra in 2015. Emperor Leo III began a period of applying this policy in the Byzantine Empire based on a prohibition in the Ten Commandments. A palace in Nimrud was bulldozed as part of one of these policies by ISIL. For 10 points, name this policy that prohibits the use of religious images.

People suffering from this disease were treated by the Australian bush nurse Sister Kenny. Over 200,000 “pioneers” received a placebo as part of a nationwide trial of a treatment for this disease developed at the University of Pittsburgh. 44 people were infected by this disease due to faulty practices from Berkeley’s Cutter Labs. Dr. Hart E. Van Riper warned against this disease’s spread at certain  summer camps. A cure for this disease was the original aim of the charity March of Dimes. Polish-American scientist Albert Sabin developed an oral vaccine for this disease. For 10 points, name this disease that often causes childhood paralysis and whose vaccine was first created by Jonas Salk.

In 2018, a statue of this person was discovered in the ruins of a harbor at Berenike in Egypt. Attempts to date this person’s life include Dotted Chronology, which is based on the Five Patriarchs, and a Corrected Long Chronology based on rock carvings. In 1998, the LTTE attacked a building housing this person’s left canine tooth. After stopping the sacrifice of goats, this person befriended King  Bimbisara of Magadha. A red sandstone statue of this person at Leshan is the tallest pre-modern statue in the world. This person, who was born in Lumbini as a member of the Shakya clan, had his body parts enshrined in stupas. For 10 points, name this prince who taught the Eightfold Path after gaining enlightenment.

An Italian pioneer of this technology gave rise to a trend for “Lunardi skirts” in England. Enthusiasm for this technology in France diminished after a 1785 accident that killed Jean-François Pilâtre de Rozier . It’s not the telegraph, but a Corps that used this technology to gather intelligence at the Battle of Antietam was led by Thaddeus S. C. Lowe. This technology powered bombs that killed six people in Bly, Oregon in the only fatal  Fu-Go long-distance attack during World War II. In France, this technology was pioneered by the Montgolfier brothers and later used by Léon Gambetta to escape the Siege of Paris. For 10 points, name this technology that Jean-Pierre Blanchard used in 1785 to float across the English Channel.

During a renaissance in this city, Anton Koberger printed an encyclopedic Chronicle. It’s not Aachen, but the Golden Bull of 1356 granted this city the right to host the first diet of a Holy Roman Emperor. Much later, 152 anti-aircraft searchlights were used to make a “cathedral of light” in this city. A speech given in this city by Julius Streicher to an audience of 700,000 appears in a  propaganda film by a woman who later directed Olympia. Some “subsequent” events in this city concerned the makers of Zyklon B. Robert H. Jackson represented US interests at an event in this city’s Palace of Justice that sentenced Hermann Göring to death. For 10 points, name this German city that hosted a series of Nazi war trials.

A company in this industry colloquially known as Poverty and Death operated a facility in Senghenydd  where 440 people were killed in October 1913. An alliance between workers in this industry and gay rights activists inspired the film Pride. On Vesting Day in 1947, one country nationalized this industry under the NCB. A 1973 strike in this industry prompted the Three-Day Week under the  Heath government. A union of workers in this industry fought the so-called Battle of Orgreave under the leadership of Arthur Scargill. The first commercial deployment of Thomas Newcomen’s steam engine was to pump water for this industry. For 10 points, the ironclad HMS Devastation was fueled exclusively from what industry’s outputs?

This process necessitated the creation of highly-bureaucratized states according to Karl Wittfogel’s controversial book Oriental Despotism. The Shaluf Stele contains evidence of a structure used for this process sometimes named after Necho II. Rats legendarily caused the destruction of a structure used for this process in Ma’rib in 570 CE. This process was accomplished by ancient Iranian  qanats and lever-like shadufs. Precursors to Archimedes’s Screw have been suggested to aid in this process at the Hanging Gardens of Babylon. Overdoing this process can lead to overdrafting and salination. For 10 points, name this task accomplished by ditches that filled up during the flooding of the Nile.

One of these events prompted Brazil to establish the Proálcool  program. The so-called “MEOW Speech” responding to one of these events was delivered by a president whose namesake doctrine, crafted by Zbigniew Brzezinski , called for using military force to prevent future events of this type. One of these events gave way to a “glut” in the following decade thanks to the  Prudhoe Bay complex coming fully online. In response to one of these events, Richard Nixon signed the National Maximum Speed Limit law. One of these events was launched by King Faisal during the Yom Kippur War and led to a turn away from the Big Three of Detroit. For 10 points, name these events, two of which in the 1970s were caused by a decision to block exports by OPEC.

During one of these events, William Boghurst wrote his Loimographia. John Graunt gained entrance to the Royal Society through several “bills” he compiled during these events. Queen Elizabeth I threatened to hang anyone who followed her to Windsor Castle during one of these events in 1563. Edward III issued the Ordinance of Laborers to fix  wages during one of these events. Daniel Defoe kept a journal of a “year” during one of these events which may have been ended by the Great Fire of London. An urban legend claims that the nursery rhyme “Ring Around the Rosie” originated during one of these events. For 10 points, Europe’s population was nearly halved during what type of event in the mid-1300s?

Despite not having this affiliation, Grace Growdon Galloway had her property seized by coverture laws. Charles Inglis founded a university as part of a group of these people who left a city on Evacuation Day. Boston King received a certificate of freedom as one of the many examples of these people with African heritage who settled in Nova Scotia. Colonel Tye and other members of this affiliation formed the  Ethiopian Regiment after Lord Dunmore’s Proclamation. A militia of this affiliation was defeated at the Battle of Kings Mountain. People with this affiliation were punished with tarring and feathering. For 10 points, name these people who sided with the British and fought the Patriots during the American Revolution.

In 1903, a Swedish feminist named Lizzy Lind af Hageby snuck into a university in this city and exposed a vivisection scandal in the Brown Dog Affair. Common Cause promoted a 1913 Great Pilgrimage that ended in this city and attracted 50,000 supporters of the NUWSS. Prisoners at this city’s Holloway Prison were temporarily released via the  Cat and Mouse Act to counter hunger strikes. Women in this city were targeted by a man who wrote the “Dear Boss” and “From Hell” letters. The WSPU was founded in this capital city by Emmeline Pankhurst to advocate for the right of women to vote. For 10 points, name this capital city where the Whitechapel Murders were committed by Jack the Ripper.

In this city, Leon Despres led vocal opposition to a mayor and often had his microphone cut off during speeches. Ed Vrdolyak  led 29 city councilmen in opposing another mayor of this city during the so-called “Council Wars.” This city’s mayor Jane Byrne was criticized for occupying a public housing project as a publicity stunt. Judge Julius Hoffman presided over a trial regarding events in this city, during which Bobby  Seale was gagged and bound. This city’s first Black mayor was Harold Washington. Abraham Ribicoff criticized the “Gestapo tactics’’ used in handling protests in this city. For 10 points, Richard J. Daley was mayor of what city that hosted the 1968 Democratic National Convention?

People of this ethnicity controlled cattle trade in the ubuhake system. This ethnicity’s Nyiginya  clan were the ruling mwamis of a kingdom whose last ruler, Kigeli  V, lost power in a revolution termed the “Wind of Destruction.” A conflict between rebels of this ethnicity and the MRND was paused by the Arusha Accords. During Operation  Turquoise, the French established a “safe zone” for this ethnicity. Paul Rusesabagina  allowed people of this ethnicity fleeing akazu to stay in his hotel. A leader of this ethnicity named Paul Kagame  became president after a 1994 event in which Interahamwe  militias murdered upwards of 500,000 people of this ethnicity. For 10 points, name this ethnic group targeted by the Hutus in the Rwandan Genocide.

A leader of this modern-day country gave a “fire mass” during the “mist hardships” that killed over 20 percent of this country’s population. People fleeing this country’s poor climate moved to Kinmount, Ontario before establishing a colony near Lake Winnipeg. In 2015, this country finally repealed a 400-year-old law that led locals to kill Basque sailors on sight. The  Old Covenant reduced the power of an assembly in this country whose participants gave speeches at the Law Rock. The 1784 eruption of Laki in this country resulted in a worldwide cooling. The Treaty of Kiel transferred control of this modern-day country from Norway to Denmark. For 10 points, what island country is governed from the Althing?

In 1795, Jean-Charles Pichegru unusually ordered one of these actions against the remnants of the Dutch fleet on the Zuiderzee. One of these actions was misdirected due to an ambiguous arm wave from George Bingham, 3rd Earl of Lucan. In The Face of Battle, John Keegan argued this tactic was effective only when it induced panic and explained why 12 separate instances of it against  “squares” failed at Waterloo. Napoleon typically employed an artillery barrage before one of these actions was undertaken by his cuirassiers . The Earl of Cardigan led one of these events at the Battle of Balaclava that resulted in a 40 percent casualty rate. For 10 points, name this tactic taken by the Light Brigade during the Crimean War.

These people routinely lost claims to land due to the “ten-owner rule.” In 1977, OMAC activists from this group allied with a Trades Council to stop the construction of a housing estate on Bastion Point Reserve. The 2022 biopic Whina  celebrated an activist of these people who staged a 1975 Land March to assert treaty rights. The Boyd Massacre decreased contact between this group and  pākehā. In the 19th century, these people adapted their pā villages to better defend against newly introduced weapons. An 1840 treaty asserting these people would retain “sovereignty” of their lands was signed with William Hobson. For 10 points, the Treaty of Waitangi  was signed between white settlers and what Indigenous people of New Zealand?

In a party convention during this election, a candidate described community organizations as “spread like stars throughout the Nation.” A candidate in this election dropped out after reusing phrases from a Neil Kinnock speech. An ad in this election showing actors walking in and out of a building targeted a candidate who was asked if he would still oppose the death penalty if his  wife Kitty was a victim of a violent crime. That candidate in this election was targeted by the “Willie Horton” ad. This election’s winning candidate lost in the next election in part due to his broken promise of “Read my lips: no new taxes.” For 10 points, name this presidential election where Michael Dukakis lost to George H.W. Bush.

Numerous royal rituals were recorded in this language in the Uigwe . A woodblock version of the Tripitaka in this language was printed during invasions by the Khitans. The Gabo Reform, which regulated official documents written in this language, was passed by a king whose death sparked the March 1st Movement. A system for this language was created by a king who destroyed an island base for  wokou pirates in the Gihae  Expedition. This language’s “Old” form ended with the fall of the Silla Kingdom. In the 15th century, the Hall of Worthies created a treatise outlining a written script for this language which replaced the Chinese-based hanja. For 10 points, Sejong the Great developed what language’s Hangul alphabet?

Soldiers argued that this person was cryptically mentioned in a set of erotic correspondences written to the Italian attaché Alessandro Panizzardi. While being arrested, Charles Maurras  supposedly shouted that this person got revenge; Maurras founded Action Française  during an event involving this person. The newspaper La Libre Parole frequently attacked this person based on documents that included a  “bordereau” discovered in a wastebasket. Georges Picquart  investigated actions supposedly committed by this person after he was sent to Devil’s Island in 1895 for the crimes of Ferdinand Esterhazy. For 10 points, Emile Zola penned “J’accuse” in defense of what Jewish military officer who was accused of treason?

Description acceptable. The first evidence for this event comes from a discussion of a “sentry-box” in a letter to Peter Collinson, who discussed this event at the Royal Society. George Richmann at the University of St. Petersburg died trying to replicate this event in 1753. A future Loyalist Governor assisted in this event according to details related by  Joseph Priestley. Equipment used in this event included a protective wax handle and some hemp string connected to a Leyden jar. Thomas Dalibard replicated this experiment in France, where its originator would serve as an ambassador. This experiment was originally to be done atop a church spire in Philadelphia. For 10 points, name this 1752 experiment involving a Founding Father and a storm.

Studies of this archaeological site coined koulourai as a term for bread-shaped pits. Piet de Jong restored frescos of dolphins at this site, where Theodore Fyfe barely restored the Shrines of the Double Axes. A gypsum throne at this site was surrounded by a fresco of a griffin. Figurines created at this site depict women with bare breasts and holding  snakes in their hands. This site’s 1450 BCE destruction has been attributed either to an eruption on Thera or to a Mycenaean invasion, as evidenced by Linear B script. At this site, stucco panels of women leaping over bulls were studied by Sir Arthur Evans. For 10 points, name this Minoan palace complex on Crete that legendarily contained the Minotaur’s labyrinth.

Settlement to this region was prevented by a 600-mile long series of trees and ditches known as the Willow Palisade. Indigenous inhabitants of this region’s Sixty-Four Villages included the Daur people, who were targeted by mounted bandits called hónghúzi. The Lytton Report denounced an invasion of this region that occurred under the pretext of a  false flag operation to blow up a railway. This region is named after a people who organized under the Eight Banners and were led by the Aisin-Gioro clan. A puppet government established in this region was led by the last Qīng Emperor, Pǔyí. Port Arthur and Mukden are cities in, for 10 points, what region in Northeast China that Japan invaded in 1931?

During this decade, 250,000 private citizens joined the government-sponsored American Protective League. A bill in this decade was near-unanimously passed except for a sole dissenting vote from Meyer London. In this decade, Congress refused to seat Wisconsin representative Victor Berger, and the Statue of Liberty was damaged in the Black Tom explosion. An activist was arrested in this decade after a speech made in  Canton, Ohio. That activist, like Alexander Berkman and Emma Goldman, was prosecuted under an Espionage Act passed in this decade. A president was re-elected in this decade on the campaign slogan “He Kept Us Out of War.” For 10 points, name this decade where the Zimmerman Telegram helped bring the US into World War I.

In a 1929 debate, this person humiliated Lothrop Stoddard for claiming that Stoddard’s system of “bi-racialism” did not mean discrimination. This person used letters written to Franklin Sanborn to write a 1909 biography of John Brown. This person paired poetry with unrelated sheet music to begin the chapters of a book that ends by describing “sorrow songs.” This person employed Walter  White at his newspaper, The Crisis. This person wrote “the problem of the 20th century is the problem of the color line” in the introduction to a collection that challenged Booker T. Washington’s ideas on Black education. For 10 points, The Souls of Black Folk was written by what African-American activist who founded the NAACP?

An Oscar-nominated 1976 film about this person triggered an incident where Marion Barry was shot and 100 other DC residents were taken hostage. A journalist known as “Charb” contributed to a 2013 “Life” of this person, earning his place on a most-wanted list. In 2006, a controversy named for this person resulted in widespread protests against the Jyllands-Posten  newspaper at numerous  Danish embassies. In 2010, Molly Norris organized a “day” named for this person after Viacom censored a Trey Parker and Matt Stone TV episode about him. After cartoons of this person were published, a mass shooting took place at the offices of Charlie Hebdo. For 10 points, name this founder of Islam.

This man reduced the Anglican Church’s influence at Cambridge after winning a surprisingly close election against the Earl of Powis to become its chancellor. In a speech at Exeter Hall, this man publicly endorsed Thomas Fowell-Buxton’s efforts to abolish slavery. For an event organized by Henry Cole and this man, Joseph  Paxton erected a building made from cast iron and plate glass. The Kohinoor diamond was exhibited at an event organized by this man often named for the quickly-constructed building in which it was held, the Crystal Palace. This grandfather of Nicholas II of Russia was mourned by his wife for 40 years following his 1861 death. For 10 points, name this husband of Queen Victoria.

This politician’s declaration that “the respect for the rights of others is peace” has long been a political rallying cry. After returning from exile, this politician attached his name to a law that ended a separate legal system for the military and clergy. The Convention of London was a response to this politician declaring a two-year postponement of debt repayments. The church-backed Felix  Zuloaga opposed this politician in the Reform War. This leader declared a national holiday after French troops under Charles de Lorencez  failed to seize the fortifications at Puebla. This Zapotec speaker was elected governor of his native state of Oaxaca. For 10 points, name this first indigenous president of Mexico.

During this conflict, the printing press of the Herald of Freedom was melted down for a “second edition” of cannonballs that destroyed Fort Titus. A speech made about this conflict compared a senator to Don Quixote. This conflict involved fighting at the Wakarusa River Valley. The New England Emigrant Aid Company provided  arms for one faction in this conflict. The Free State Hotel was targeted by a side in this conflict. Andrew Butler was targeted in a speech about the “Crime Against” the location of this conflict. During this conflict, the Lecompton Constitution drew the support of armed border ruffians. For 10 points, name this conflict between pro- and anti-slavery factions in a state with capital at Topeka.

After this event, one leader stayed at Ian Fleming’s estate for a month amid concerns of his benzedrine addiction. Joel Beinin traced a mass expulsion that occurred during this event to distrust from the Lavon Affair two years prior. The Sixth Fleet blocked the IMF from sending aid during this event despite one leader’s insistence that the Americans would “lie doggo.” One side during this event launched Operation  Musketeer to open up the Straits of Tiran. Lester Pearson won a Nobel Peace Prize for mediating this event’s end, after which Anthony Eden resigned. For 10 points, name this 1956 conflict in which France, Britain, and Israel jointly invaded Egypt over a structure nationalized by Gamal Abdel Nasser.

A controversy named for these objects was resolved when Deputy Secretary Roswell Gilpatric found only 10 examples of R-7s in Corona photos. In 1984, a young Ash Carter told Congress that a proposed system of X-rays would be ineffective against these objects. A technology to counter these items, the Nike Zeus, was canceled by Robert McNamara. Canada installed  Bomarc examples of these items instead of sticking with the Avro Arrow. They’re not bombers, but the Kennedy campaign exploited the false notion that the US had a “gap” in these weapons. These weapons would have been destroyed by the Reagan-era SDI program, which critics dubbed “Star Wars.” For 10 points, name these weapons fired from silos.

One historian claimed that people from this region descended from the underworld god Dis  and thus emphasized night more than day. Aurelian claimed the title Restitutor Orbis after defeating a splinter state in this region led by Postumus. A king from this region threw his sword on scales and declared “vae victis”  after winning the Battle of the  Allia. Aulus Hirtius partially authored a series of works that describes campaigns against this region’s Helvetii tribe. Brennus was from this region, where one commander used contravallation to defeat Vercingetorix  at the Siege of Alesia. For 10 points, Julius Caesar wrote a set of commentaries on his campaigns in what Roman province, which encompasses much of modern France?

Thirty years of experiments in this industry are recorded in the journals of 18th-century Yale president Ezra Stiles. John Lombe of Derby  may have been assassinated in 1722 for stealing a “doubler” used in this industry from the Sardinians. Jean-de-Dieu Soult  led an army into Lyon to suppress workers in this industry in the first Canut  Revolt. Equipment needed for this industry was stolen by two  Nestorian monks on a mission funded by Justinian the Great. Tash Rabat was one of the caravanserai in Kyrgyzstan that was part of a network named for this industry. This industry was promoted in colonial New England through the importation of mulberry trees. For 10 points, name this industry which also names a “road” to China.

In 1704, this currency was the first to be decimalized. It’s not the franc, but in 1768, a ruler replaced copper versions of this currency with promissory notes printed by the Assignation Bank. Hard currencies rather than this currency were required to purchase luxury goods in state-run Torgsin stores. A 1998 “crisis” named for this currency followed a fall in the  MICEX  rate in a country damaged by “shock therapy.” The Comecon used a “convertible” form of this currency, which was produced at a state-owned factory in Goznak. The official exchange rate for this currency against the dollar was amended to be closer to the black-market rate during the era of perestroika. For 10 points, name this Russian currency.

Despite hearing news about this event, officials at Clark Field failed to swiftly implement the Rainbow 5 plan. The first Roberts Commission investigated this event. A few days before this event, Cordell Hull delivered a note embargoing oil exports. This event led to the demotion of Husband Kimmel. A participant in this event was controversially given good treatment after crashing on  Niihau. For heroics during this event, Doris Miller became the first Black man to earn a Navy Cross. Rear Admiral Isaac C. Kidd and 1,176 other crewmen were killed on a ship that now serves as a memorial of this event. For 10 points, the USS Arizona was sunk during what surprise attack that brought the US into World War II?

One side in this conflict rallied around a slogan that followed the name of a leader in this conflict with the phrase “or we burn the country.” Tensions in this conflict increased when the Air Force Intelligence Directorate dumped a mutilated body in the city of Daraa. This conflict began with a mass “Revolution of Dignity” against the Alawite-dominated ruling party. An American  president refused to further escalate this conflict after one side crossed a “red line” and perpetrated the Ghouta chemical attack. A photograph shows a two-year-old refugee from this conflict named Alan Kurdi who drowned when attempting to cross to Greece in 2015. For 10 points, name this ongoing conflict in a country mostly led by Bashar al-Assad.

In the 1990s, researchers used DNA from corpses at Kerameikos to correlate a disease outbreak during this war to typhoid fever. A passage about this war inspired Graham T. Allison to coin the name of a “trap” often invoked in discussions of US-China relations. A speech that offered “comfort, not condolences,” to bereaved citizens during this war was given by a leader killed during a  plague outbreak. During this war’s Archidamian phase, one city was defended by the Long Walls. The argument that “the strong do what they can, and the weak suffer what they must” was invoked during one side’s siege of Melos during this war. Thucydides wrote a history of, for 10 points, what war between Athens and Sparta?

Profits from one of these businesses allowed Matsutarō Shōriki to found baseball’s Yomiuri Giants. In Europe, these businesses emerged from smaller-scale avvisi enterprises. The UK’s Minister of Aircraft Production in World War II, Lord Beaverbrook, made his fortune running these businesses. The most successful of these businesses in the US was bought by  Punch Sulzberger a year before the landmark Sullivan decision. In 1910, the McNamara brothers were imprisoned for bombing one of these businesses in Los Angeles. A British business of this type closed in 2011 following a phone hacking scandal and was owned by Rupert Murdoch, who also owns one called The Sun. For 10 points, name these businesses that include the LA Times.

The Geddes Committee recommended consolidating these places to increase competitiveness. The 1920 “Belfast Pogrom” primarily targeted Catholic workers at these places such as Harland and Wolff. A man who organized workers in one of these places ran for president on the slogan “I do not want to, but I have to” and possibly worked as a secret agent under the alias “Bolek.” Russian examples of these places were built after  Peter the Great worked at one in Amsterdam in disguise. The firing of Anna Walentynowicz  from one of these places named for Lenin in Gdańsk ignited the Solidarity movement. For 10 points, name these places that built vessels for the White Star Line’s Olympic class, such as the RMS Titanic.

This dynasty was the earliest to create artworks featuring the motif of a beast-like face looking at two dragons. This dynasty’s cruel final ruler allegedly tortured prisoners with red-hot copper pillars at his concubine’s suggestion. The remains of sixteen human sacrifices were found in the tomb of this dynasty’s general Fù Hǎo, located near present-day Ānyáng. This dynasty’s last ruler lost the Battle of  Mùyě. This dynasty’s shamans analyzed heat-induced cracking patterns alongside pictographs on objects like ox scapulae. Oracle bones were developed during this dynasty, whose successor was the first to justify their rule through the Mandate of Heaven. For 10 points, name this Chinese dynasty that preceded the Zhōu.

In a cartoon, this politician is depicted hauling a block with the help of “King Andy,” referencing negotiations this politician had with Eduard de Stoeckl. This politician defeated three-term incumbent governor William Marcy in an election. This politician’s Republican presidential candidacy was derailed over associations with Thurlow Weed, who had left the Anti-Masons with him. This man declared that there was a  “higher law” than the Constitution in a speech opposing the Compromise of 1850. This Cabinet member, who was stabbed by Lewis Powell, was panned for a 7.2 million dollar purchase. For 10 points, name this Secretary of State under Abraham Lincoln, who oversaw the purchase of Alaska in his namesake “folly.”

John “Hurry” Urry betrayed a plot to kidnap three noblemen from this kingdom known simply as “The Incident.” The Earl of Arran’s mother threatened to shoot him in the bowels during his attempted invasion of this kingdom. The Chaseabout Raid was a rebellion against a ruler of this kingdom who employed the courtier David Rizzio. September 3rd marks two losses experienced by this kingdom a year apart at  Dunbar and Worcester. The Covenanters revolted during the Bishops’ Wars following an attempt to impose the Book of Common Prayer on this primarily Presbyterian kingdom. This kingdom joined with its southern neighbor in a “Union of Crowns” that elevated James VI. For 10 points, name this kingdom ruled from Edinburgh.

This sea’s oldest-known archaeological site, which consists of a shell midden made by the Ortoiroid people, is Banwari Trace. A matrilineal culture from around this sea made three-point stone sculptures of spirits called zemis. Agüeybaná  and Enriquillo  were leaders of an indigenous group that live in this sea who took the title cacique . The  Garifuna descended from inhabitants of an island in this sea. Ciboney  is a dialect of a language from this sea which is the source of the English words hurricane, barbecue, and cassava. Indigenous peoples often joined the crews of buccaneers active in this sea such as Henry Morgan. For 10 points, name this sea where Taíno  people live on Hispaniola.
